text: When I prepare for bed, I notice my thoughts and choose to let them go instead of engaging with them.
During evenings, I create a calm routine that helps my body and mind transition into rest mode.
When I feel anxious about sleep, I notice the worry and choose to breathe and relax instead.
I let racing thoughts or worries keep me awake long after I want to sleep.
When I wake up during the night, I notice the wakefulness and choose to stay calm instead of worrying about it.
I recognize when my mind is avoiding the next day by staying awake, and I choose to face it with rest instead.
When I feel the urge to stay up late, I notice the pattern and choose to honor my sleep schedule instead.
I let stress or unresolved emotions from the day disrupt my ability to fall asleep or stay asleep.
When I notice difficulty falling asleep, I stay calm and let my body relax instead of forcing sleep.
I see when screens or stimulation are keeping me awake, and I choose to disconnect and wind down instead.
When I wake up too early, I notice it and choose to rest quietly instead of worrying about lost sleep.
I let irregular sleep schedules or poor bedtime habits control my rest and daily energy.
When I feel tension in my body at bedtime, I notice it and use breathing or relaxation to release it.
I recognize when my mind is overthinking at night, and I choose to redirect my attention to rest instead.
When I notice my sleep quality affecting my mood or focus, I adjust my habits to support better rest.
I let anxiety about not sleeping well create more stress and make sleep problems worse.
When I feel the pull to stay up working or scrolling, I notice it and choose to protect my sleep time instead.
I see when my daily rhythm is disrupting my sleep, and I choose to create more consistent patterns.
When I notice my body needs rest, I honor that need instead of pushing through exhaustion.
I let poor sleep habits or lack of routine prevent me from getting the rest I need.
